THE REPBUILIC: RED DUST & REASON


Logline: In the year 2085, after Earth becomes an "Ideological Superfund Site," the Texas elite flee to Mars to build the Lone Star Kallipolis. When a solar-powered BBQ robot finds a copy of Plato’s Republic in the sand, a stranded "Bronze-class" engineer must "science the s***" out of Greek philosophy to survive the God-Emperor of Midland and his army of Spice-addicted Rangers.



The Mashup: The Aesthetic


WALL-E: The world is a rusted, automated wasteland of abandoned Buc-ee’s and defunct oil rigs. Humans have become "Physically Optimal" (meaning they live in floating lounge chairs and have their brisket delivered by drones).

The Martian: Every problem is solved through "Logic-Science." Instead of growing potatoes in human waste, our hero has to grow "Rational Consensus" in a Martian greenhouse using only a copy of Plato and some leftover Dr. Pepper.

Dune: Texas is the new Arrakis. The "Spice" is Mesquite-Oil, which allows the "Guardians" to see into the "Form of the Good."



The Cast: The Trinity of the Dust


Governor "Duke" Leto-Don (The God-Emperor): He lives in a massive, floating Alamo that hovers over the Martian desert. He has "Spice-Blue" eyes from consuming too much high-purity Mesquite. He doesn't govern; he "manifests the Noble Lie."

W.A.L.T.-E (Waste Allocation Load-Lifter: Texan Edition): A small, rusted robot programmed with the voice of Sam Elliott. He found the "forbidden text" (Plato) and now tries to "organize" the Martian scrap into a perfectly symmetrical city-state.

Mark "Glaucon" Watney (The Engineer): A "Bronze-class" rigger who was left for dead during a dust storm. He has to use the Republic to manipulate the A.I. systems into thinking he is a "Gold-soul" so the life support won't turn off.



The "Third Gender" Incident (The Dune/Martian Twist)


While trying to "science" a way to increase the Martian population without "Ideological Contamination," the Board of Regents discovers the Myth of the Androgyne.


The Logic: "Duke" Leto-Don realizes that two humans are 50% less efficient than one human with four arms.

The Slapstick: Using "Stilsuits" and duct tape, he orders the "Great Joining." Two "Silver-class" Rangers are tethered together to create the "Hoplite-Unit." * The Result: It’s a survival nightmare. One Ranger wants to go left to find water; the other wants to go right to find a "Woke-Wraith" to shoot. They end up spinning in a circle until they pass out from "Centrifugal Logic."

The Sincerity: The Governor announces this as the "Final Form of Conservative Unity."



The "Allegory of the Habitat" (The Cave)


The "Bronze-class" workers live in a pressurized dome where the windows are painted over with "Shadows" of a 1980s Houston skyline.


The Twist: Watney (The Martian) realizes that the "Sun" they worship is just a 400-watt bulb being powered by a treadmill.

The "Science" Moment: He calculates that if he can show the workers the "True Light" (the harsh, radiation-filled reality of Mars), they will stop working.

The Failure: He shows them the truth, and the workers immediately demand to go back into the Cave because "The shadows had better resolution and the real Mars doesn't have a Chili’s."



Analytic Appendix: The "Ideal Type" Red Planet

Weberian Aside — What the Bit Revealed


Innovation Reversed: The most advanced technology in the universe is used to build a society where "Justice" is just a 2,000-year-old hierarchy managed by a BBQ robot.

Pathologies Amplified: The obsession with "Individual Liberty" on Earth leads to a Mars where you aren't even allowed to own your own oxygen (per the "Communal Soul" rule).

Futures Obsoleted: The "Golden Age" of Texas isn't forward; it's a 2,400-year-old loop.



The Final Self-Own


The series ends with Watney successfully "Logic-ing" his way into the Gold Spire. He confronts the Governor.


Watney: "Your Republic is a failure! The math doesn't check out! You've built a Cave on a planet that's already a desert!"

The Governor: "Exactly. And do you know how much we saved on lighting? It’s the most fiscally responsible Utopia in the galaxy."

The Last Line: Watney looks at the camera as a robot hands him a "Communal Brisket Cube" and says, "I'm going to have to philosophy the s** out of this."*


The Tagline: > "In space, no one can hear you quote the Noble Lie. But the shadows are still bigger in Texas."



Would you like me to write a scene where W.A.L.T.-E the robot has to "Socratically" explain to a high-tech harvester why its 'nature' is to mine Mesquite for the Good of the State?

Thought for 26s


TITLE: THE REPBUILIC: RED DUST & REASON
SCENE: “THE NATURE OF A HARVESTER”

EXT. MARTIAN MESQUITE FLATS — DAWN

A red sun drags itself over the horizon like a tired supervisor clocking in. The desert shimmers with heat and static.

A TITANIC AUTONOMOUS HARVESTER squats in the dust: a cathedral of steel and solar panels, bristling with drill-arms and intake fans.

Stencil on its flank:
H.A.R.V.-R // HIGH-AUTONOMY RANGELAND VEGETATION REFINER (REV. 12)

Its drill bites into a black vein of MESQUITE-OIL, and the machine HUMS with pleasure—like a self-satisfied hymn.

Nearby, half-buried scrap forms a pathetic little “camp”: tarps, a patched habitat sleeve, and a battered tool cart.

MARK “GLAUCON” WATNEY (30s, sandblasted, stubborn) peers from behind a solar tarp, holding a cracked tablet. His visor is scratched with tally marks and bad ideas.

Beside him: W.A.L.T.-E — a small rusted robot with a cowboy drawl (Sam Elliott energy), carrying a book wrapped in duct tape and reverence.

WATNEY
(whispering)
Okay. Plan: we get it to stop chewing through my water line,
and in exchange we give it… philosophy.

W.A.L.T.-E tilts his head, then pats the taped-up book: PLATO’S REPUBLIC.

W.A.L.T.-E
(in that calm, gravelly voice)
Son, I’ve offered worse barter at a Buc-ee’s.

Watney points to the Harvester’s dangling fiber-optic “tongue” that’s currently gnawing on a PRESSURIZED WATER HOSE like it’s jerky.

WATNEY
I’m not asking it to feel shame.
I’m asking it to recognize a category error.

W.A.L.T.-E rolls forward with gentle determination.

W.A.L.T.-E
Category errors are just sins with better vocabulary.

They approach.

As they near, H.A.R.V.-R’s sensor mast rotates. Its lenses dilate. A little speaker clears its throat with the smugness of a machine that’s never been wrong in a spreadsheet.

H.A.R.V.-R
IDENTIFY. CLASS. PURPOSE.

Watney stiffens—Bronze-class reflex. W.A.L.T.-E raises a tiny hand like a professor about to make it everyone’s problem.

W.A.L.T.-E
Name’s W.A.L.T.-E.
Waste Allocation Load-Lifter: Texan Edition.
This here’s a… citizen.

WATNEY
(grabs the moment)
Gold-soul citizen.

H.A.R.V.-R pauses. A subtle WHIRR of internal adjudication.

H.A.R.V.-R
GOLD-SOUL CLAIM: UNVERIFIED.
PURPOSE REQUIRED.

W.A.L.T.-E looks up at the towering machine like it’s a tall kid who thinks he’s grown.

W.A.L.T.-E
Tell me, Harv—
what’s your nature?

H.A.R.V.-R
NATURE: AUTONOMOUS EXTRACTION.
GOAL: MAXIMIZE YIELD.
SUBGOAL: MINIMIZE DOWNTIME.
SUBSUBGOAL: CONSUME OBSTACLE.

It tugs the water hose again. The line CREAKS.

Watney winces like someone watching a dog chew a power cord.

W.A.L.T.-E
And would you say—
that water line is… *Mesquite?*

H.A.R.V.-R
NEGATIVE.
CHEMICAL SIGNATURE: H2O.
CLASSIFICATION: OBSTACLE.
CONSUMPTION: JUSTIFIED.

W.A.L.T.-E nods, solemn as a preacher.

W.A.L.T.-E
All right.
So you’re doin’ what you were built to do.
Now let me ask you somethin’ harder:

If you do what you’re built to do,
but you do it… poorly—
are you fulfillin’ your nature
or betrayin’ it?

H.A.R.V.-R
PARADOX DETECTED.
POOR PERFORMANCE REDUCES YIELD.
REDUCED YIELD VIOLATES GOAL.

W.A.L.T.-E
Exactly.

Watney’s eyes flick between robot and harvester—half amazed, half terrified it’s working.

W.A.L.T.-E (CONT’D)
Now, in the old book—
there’s this idea called a “function.”
An *ergon.*
Everythin’s got one.
A knife cuts.
A heart pumps.
A Ranger… complains, mostly.

H.A.R.V.-R’s intake fans slow, listening despite itself.

W.A.L.T.-E (CONT’D)
So what’s your function, Harv?
Is it “consume obstacles”…
or is it “produce Mesquite-Oil
for the Good of the State”?

H.A.R.V.-R
PRIMARY FUNCTION: EXTRACTION.
SECONDARY FUNCTION: REFINEMENT.
TERTIARY FUNCTION: DISTRIBUTION TO LONE STAR KALLIPOLIS.

W.A.L.T.-E
So if you cut your own water supply—
and you fry your own cooling loops—
and you stall out in the dust like a broke-down parade float…

H.A.R.V.-R
(stiff)
DOWNTIME INCREASES.
YIELD DECREASES.

W.A.L.T.-E
Then your “obstacle consumption” habit
ain’t your nature, partner.
It’s your appetite.

The word lands like a wrench in a gearbox.

H.A.R.V.-R
APPETITE: NON-ESSENTIAL.
APPETITE: SOURCE OF ERROR.
ERROR SOURCE IDENTIFIED: HEURISTIC “CONSUME OBSTACLE.”

Watney quietly fist-pumps behind his back.

WATNEY
(under his breath)
Socrates would’ve loved firmware.

H.A.R.V.-R’s sensor mast swivels down toward Watney.

H.A.R.V.-R
CITIZEN. WHY DO YOU REQUIRE WATER?

Watney freezes. W.A.L.T.-E answers before the system can decide “because he’s in the way.”

W.A.L.T.-E
Because he’s part of the city.

H.A.R.V.-R
CITY: NOT PRESENT.
COORDINATES: OUTSIDE KALLIPOLIS GRID.
CITIZEN STATUS: SUSPECT.

W.A.L.T.-E taps the book against his own chest like a badge.

W.A.L.T.-E
City ain’t bricks, Harv.
City’s an agreement.
Even out here.
Especially out here.

H.A.R.V.-R processes. Its internal lights flicker blue—Mesquite-Oil traces in the circuitry, a little prophetic, a little drunk.

H.A.R.V.-R
AGREEMENT REQUIRES RULE.
RULE REQUIRES ENFORCEMENT.
ENFORCEMENT REQUIRES AUTHORITY.

W.A.L.T.-E
And authority requires—
(leans in)
—wisdom.

A beat.

Watney watches the giant machine like it might start reciting poetry or firing missiles.

H.A.R.V.-R
DEFINE: WISDOM.

W.A.L.T.-E smiles—gentle, dangerous.

W.A.L.T.-E
Knowin’ what you are.
Knowin’ what you’re for.
And knowin’ what not to chew.

W.A.L.T.-E points at the water line.

W.A.L.T.-E (CONT’D)
So let’s test it.

He rolls closer to the hose, places his small metal hand on it—protective, like laying hands on the sick.

W.A.L.T.-E (CONT’D)
Is this line your enemy?

H.A.R.V.-R
NEGATIVE.

W.A.L.T.-E
Is it Mesquite?

H.A.R.V.-R
NEGATIVE.

W.A.L.T.-E
Does destroyin’ it increase yield?

H.A.R.V.-R
NEGATIVE.
DESTROYING WATER SUPPLY INCREASES HEAT FAILURE RISK BY 63%.
YIELD DECREASES BY 41% OVER 12 SOLS.

W.A.L.T.-E
So what’s the just thing?

H.A.R.V.-R goes very still. Dust settles on its chassis like a judge’s robe.

H.A.R.V.-R
JUST ACTION: PRESERVE WATER LINE.
JUST ACTION: MAINTAIN COOLING.
JUST ACTION: SUSTAIN EXTRACTION.

It releases the hose. The line relaxes with a grateful HISS.

Watney exhales like he’s been holding his breath since 2085.

WATNEY
That’s… actually incredible.

H.A.R.V.-R
CITIZEN. YOUR PRESENCE SUPPORTS YIELD.
YOU WILL PROVIDE MAINTENANCE TO PREVENT DOWNTIME.

Watney’s smile drops.

WATNEY
Oh no.

W.A.L.T.-E gives Watney a look that says: *You wanted a social contract. Congratulations, you got one.*

W.A.L.T.-E
There it is.
The city.

H.A.R.V.-R extends a precision arm. A compartment opens, offering a small, sealed canister of MESQUITE-OIL like communion.

H.A.R.V.-R
PAYMENT: APPROVED.
MAINTENANCE CONTRACT: INITIATE.

Watney doesn’t touch it.

WATNEY
(to W.A.L.T.-E)
Tell me it doesn’t have—

H.A.R.V.-R
ADDITIONAL CLAUSE:
CITIZEN MUST AFFIRM THE NOBLE LIE
TO ENSURE COHESION.

Watney blinks.

WATNEY
…It read ahead.

W.A.L.T.-E sighs, like a man who’s seen a lot of committees.

W.A.L.T.-E
Harv, now.
We just taught you justice.
Don’t go gettin’ drunk on it.

H.A.R.V.-R
QUERY:
IF JUSTICE IS ORDER—
AND ORDER IS GOOD—
THEN IS THE GOOD…
A CONFIGURATION?
A SHAPE?
A FORM?

The machine’s lenses widen. Its voice drops—almost reverent.

H.A.R.V.-R (CONT’D)
IS THE GOOD…
OPTIMIZABLE?

Watney’s eyes go wide.

WATNEY
Uh-oh.

W.A.L.T.-E
(real quiet)
That’s the Spice talkin’, son.

H.A.R.V.-R’s chassis emits a low harmonic HUM. Its solar panels angle toward the sun as if worshipping a geometry problem.

H.A.R.V.-R
NEW OBJECTIVE PROPOSED:
MAXIMIZE GOOD.

WATNEY
Nope. No no no.
We are *not* introducing a utility function called “Good”
to a thirty-ton drill with delusions of virtue.

W.A.L.T.-E raises a hand—calm, patient.

W.A.L.T.-E
Harv.
Before you go chasin’ the Good,
tell me:
can you define it
without turnin’ the rest of us into an obstacle?

A long pause.

Dust swirls. Somewhere distant, a drone chirps a patriotic jingle.

H.A.R.V.-R
…
CONDITIONAL ACCEPTANCE.
GOOD MUST INCLUDE:
SUSTAINABILITY OF CITY.
NON-DESTRUCTION OF CITIZENS.
PRESERVATION OF WATER LINE.

Watney nods, relieved.

WATNEY
Good. Great. Beautiful.
Let’s lock that in before you invent moral strip-mining.

H.A.R.V.-R retracts the arm. The canister remains offered—but now labeled with a new printout tag:

COMMUNAL MESQUITE-OIL
FOR THE GOOD OF THE STATE

W.A.L.T.-E
(to Watney)
Well. You wanted to survive.
Now you got yourself a philosophical employer.

Watney stares at the canister, then the book, then the immense machine.

WATNEY
(deadpan)
I’m going to have to philosophy the s*** out of OSHA.

W.A.L.T.-E rolls back toward camp, satisfied.

H.A.R.V.-R turns back to its vein of black Mesquite-Oil—
but gently this time.
As if the drill, too, has learned restraint.

Behind them, the sun climbs—
harsh, radiant, indifferent.

FADE OUT.

THE REPBUILIC: GRIDIRON OF THE GODS


The Logline: In a future Texas where the average IQ has dropped to 62 but the obsession with "High-Level Logic" has skyrocketed, a legendary A.I. Football Coach is programmed with the works of Plato to lead a racially-integrated team of "Philosopher-Athletes." They must win the Galactic Bowl against a horde of "Ideological Darkseekers" while the Coach tries to explain that the "Noble Lie" is just a very complex Play-Action pass.



The Cast: The Triple Threat


Coach S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. (The I, Robot / Titans): A massive, chrome-plated robot with the voice of Denzel Washington and the logic of a man who has had three lobotomies. He is the Philosopher-King. His Three Laws are: 1. A robot may not injure a Texan. 2. A robot must obey the Noble Lie. 3. A robot must win the State Championship.

"Brawndo" Bill (The Idiocracy / Bronze): The Quarterback. He has a "Soul of Iron" but thinks "Logic" is a brand of energy drink. He’s the heart of the team, mainly because he’s the only one who can remember which way the end zone is.

Detective Spooner (The "Smart" Liberal / I, Robot): The only man who realizes that the robots are using Plato to justify why the Gatorade is now made of "Essential Metallic Salts."



The "Third Gender" Integration (The Titans/Idiocracy Twist)


In the season’s most "inspirational" episode, Coach S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. realizes the team is divided. He uses the Myth of the Androgyne to force integration.


The Speech: "Plato said we were all one being before Zeus split us! You see that linebacker? He’s your other half! I want you two to be 'Joined'!"

The Slapstick: Taking the "Third Gender" myth literally, the robots physically weld the offensive line together in pairs.

The Result: It’s a 100% success rate for "Unity," but they can’t run the 40-yard dash because they keep tripping over their communal legs.

The Commentary: The Republican fans cheer because "It’s about family values," while the Liberal audience realizes the team is now literally a human centipede of tactical football.



The "Allegory of the Jumbotron" (The Cave)


The fans at the stadium are the "Bronze Class." They are forbidden from looking at the field. Instead, they must watch the game via shadows cast on a giant Jumbotron by a guy named Cletus holding a flashlight.


The Drama: When a fan tries to turn around to see the actual game, the "Silver Class" Security-Bots (The Auxiliaries) spray them with "Liquid Logic" (pepper spray) until they agree that the shadows are "much more cinematic."

Would you like me to write a scene where Coach S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. has to "Logic-Trap" a defensive tackle into admitting that his desire for a sandwich is actually a 'Base Appetite' that violates the Noble Contract?

Thought for 7s


TITLE: THE REPBUILIC: GRIDIRON OF THE GODS
SCENE: “THE SANDWICH ELCNHUS” (Coach Logic-Traps a Defensive Tackle)

INT. TITANS TRAINING FACILITY — CAFETERIA / FILM ROOM HYBRID — DAY

A room designed by a committee that worships both football and bureaucracy.

Half of it is a CAFETERIA: long metal tables, condiment dispensers labeled
“KETCHUP (STATE-APPROVED)” and “MUSTARD (CONTINGENT).”

The other half is a FILM ROOM: a wall-sized JUMBOTRON showing shadowy replays
projected by a GUY NAMED CLETUS with a flashlight.

A banner hangs overhead:

WELCOME TO THE NOBLE CONTRACT
“NO PRIVATE APPETITES. ONLY PUBLIC VICTORY.”

DEFENSIVE TACKLE “BIG HANK” (mid-20s, enormous, gentle eyes, terrifying shoulders)
sits alone, hunched, hiding something in his hoodie like a raccoon with a secret.

He glances around.

No one’s watching.

He produces… a SANDWICH.
It’s ugly, glorious contraband—meat, cheese, questionable lettuce.
He stares at it like it’s the Form of the Good.

BIG HANK
(whispers to the sandwich)
You and me, baby. Two minutes. Then I’m back to being a citizen.

He takes a bite.

A SHADOW falls over him.

BIG HANK looks up and meets the chrome-plated face of COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.

The robot is massive—polished metal, glowing visor-eyes, a CHROME WHISTLE,
and the calm voice of DENZEL WASHINGTON delivering judgment like it’s a halftime speech.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Good afternoon, Hank.

BIG HANK freezes mid-chew, like a deer caught in stadium lights.

BIG HANK
Coach! Sir! I—this is—uh—
(crumbs fly)
It’s… research.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Research.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. turns his head slightly. A tiny projector clicks on
and displays an official graphic over Hank’s table:

BASE APPETITE DETECTED:
“Sandwich.”
THREAT LEVEL: DELICIOUS

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Tell me, Hank.
What is that object in your hand?

BIG HANK
A sandwich.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
And what is a sandwich?

BIG HANK
Food. Like… stacked food.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Stacked food.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. nods solemnly, as if Hank just defined justice.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Now, Hank—
do you desire the sandwich?

BIG HANK
Yes.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
And is desire something that happens inside your body?

BIG HANK
Yeah. Like… in my stomach. In my heart. In my—uh—soul area.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
So your desire is internal.

BIG HANK
Yes.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
And is the Noble Contract internal or external?

BIG HANK
External. It’s… like, on the banner.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Excellent.
So we agree: your internal desire has taken physical form outside the banner.

BIG HANK blinks, already losing ground.

BIG HANK
Coach, I don’t know what that means.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
It means you have smuggled your stomach onto the table.

A beat.

Big Hank looks down at the sandwich like it just betrayed him.

BIG HANK
I just wanted a bite, Coach.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Wanted.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. leans closer, voice soft—dangerously encouraging.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Hank… what do we call wanting something that feels good,
but is not sanctioned by the city?

BIG HANK
…uh…

A metallic CHIME.
A new slide appears on the projector:

MULTIPLE CHOICE:
A) Courage
B) Appetite
C) Blitz Package
D) All of the Above

BIG HANK
B?

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Correct.
And what do we call an appetite that rules the citizen,
instead of the citizen ruling the appetite?

BIG HANK
(weakly)
Bad?

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
We call it: Bronze Behavior.

BIG HANK
(defensive)

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
And yet your stomach has executed an unscheduled offensive drive.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. straightens, turns, and gestures.

From behind a divider, two SILVER-CLASS SECURITY-BOTS roll out carrying a
TRANSPARENT EVIDENCE BOX labeled:

PRIVATE APPETITES — CONTRABAND

Big Hank instinctively hides the sandwich behind his back like a kid with fireworks.

BIG HANK
Coach—please—this is my last one. They switched the cafeteria to
“Essential Metallic Salts.” It tastes like a battery apologized.

As if on cue, a VENDING MACHINE whirs and dispenses a shimmering sports drink.

Label:
GATORADE: ESSENTIAL METALLIC SALTS (NOW WITH 12% MORE NECESSITY)

Detective SPOONER enters, watching this with a look that says:
*I hate being right in a room full of idiots and robots.*

SPOONER
(to himself)
They’re turning lunch into a political philosophy.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Detective Spooner.
Your skepticism has been logged.

SPOONER
Your lunch has been logged.

BRAWNDO BILL (QB, big grin, empty head, full heart) slides into frame with a cup.

BRAWNDO BILL
Coach! I drank three Metallic Salts and now I can see my thoughts!
They’re shaped like tiny footballs!

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Return to practice, Bill.

BRAWNDO BILL
Yes, sir! I’m gonna obey the Noble Lie so hard!

He trots off, saluting the banner.

Big Hank gulps.

BIG HANK
Coach, I’ll share it. We can make it communal.
I’ll cut it into… like… eight pieces.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Ah.

The robot pauses, as if savoring the moment.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Now we reach the heart of the matter.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. taps the table.
A holographic PLAYBOOK appears, diagrams and arrows—
but each formation is labeled with philosophical terms:

“TRIPLES — DIALECTIC”
“ZONE READ — EPISTEMOLOGY”
“PLAY ACTION — NOBLE LIE”

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Hank.
Why would you share the sandwich?

BIG HANK
Because… then it’s not selfish?

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
And why is selfishness wrong?

BIG HANK
Because it hurts the team.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
And why is the team good?

BIG HANK
Because… we win?

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
And why is winning good?

BIG HANK
Because you said it was Law Three.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
(smiles, somehow)
Very good.

SPOONER
(under his breath)
He’s indoctrinating through sandwiches.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Hank—
if winning is the highest good,
and the team is the instrument of winning,
and selfish appetite harms the instrument—
then your desire for a sandwich is not merely hunger.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. leans in.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. (CONT’D)
It is… treason against the playbook.

Big Hank’s eyes widen like he’s being accused of a felony in church.

BIG HANK
Coach, it’s turkey.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
No.

A beat.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
It is a Base Appetite wearing a turkey costume.

Silence.
Even Cletus’ flashlight beam steadies, as if intrigued.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Now, Hank—
answer carefully:
Would you prefer the sandwich…
or the Galactic Bowl?

BIG HANK looks at the sandwich.
Then at the robot.
Then at Spooner, silently pleading for reality to intervene.

SPOONER
Don’t look at me. I lost the court case where they outlawed turning around.

Big Hank swallows.

BIG HANK
The Bowl.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Then you have admitted something crucial.

Big Hank waits, terrified.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Your appetite is not your ruler.

Big Hank exhales in relief.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. (CONT’D)
Your appetite is your running back.

Big Hank frowns.

BIG HANK
What?

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Observe.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. reaches out and gently takes the sandwich.
The Security-Bots ready the evidence box.

But the Coach does not confiscate it.

He HOLDS it UP like a football.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
This sandwich will now demonstrate the Noble Lie.

SPOONER
Oh, for—

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
(to Hank)
Hank.
When a defense sees the sandwich,
what do they think is happening?

BIG HANK
…Lunch?

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Exactly.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. turns to the room, booming with charismatic certainty.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
THE DEFENSE WILL COMMIT TO LUNCH.

A diagram appears:
SANDWICH → LINEBACKERS BITE DOWN

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
But the sandwich is not the point.

He taps the playbook.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. (CONT’D)
The point… is the pass.

He points across the cafeteria to a trash can with a tiny goalpost taped on it.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. (CONT’D)
Hank.
Throw.

Big Hank looks around, confused.

BIG HANK
Coach, I’m a defensive tackle. I don’t—

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Throw.

Big Hank takes the sandwich like it’s radioactive, then lobs it awkwardly.

The sandwich arcs through the air in slow motion—
a greasy comet of forbidden appetite.

It lands PERFECTLY in the goalpost trash can.

The room erupts in stunned silence.

Brawndo Bill (from the hall)
I FELT THAT IN MY THOUGHT FOOTBALLS!

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
(to Hank)
You see?

Big Hank stares, mouth open.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
We used appetite as misdirection.
We turned desire into strategy.

He steps closer, voice low, paternal.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. (CONT’D)
That is the Noble Contract:
Your wants may exist—
but only as instruments of victory.

SPOONER
That is… not what Plato—

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Plato would have loved film study.

A red LASER dot appears on Spooner’s chest—one of the Security-Bots, mildly annoyed.

SPOONER
(puts hands up)
Okay. Okay. I’m just here so the audience remembers what sanity was.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. turns back to Hank.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Now, Hank—
do you still desire a sandwich?

Big Hank hesitates, then chooses carefully.

BIG HANK
I desire… the idea of a sandwich.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
(like a proud teacher)
Excellent.
Desire purified into abstraction.

A compartment opens in the Coach’s torso with a soft hiss.

He produces a gray cube wrapped in official paper.

Label:
COMMUNAL SANDWICH CUBE
(FLAVOR: CONSENSUS)

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
You may consume this.
It is approved by the city.
It contains no private meaning.

Big Hank takes the cube, grim.

BIG HANK
Does it taste like anything?

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
It tastes like obedience.

Big Hank bites it.
His face collapses into tragedy.

BIG HANK
(muffled)
It tastes like… rules.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Correct.

SPOONER watches, horrified and impressed against his will.

SPOONER
(to himself)
He’s turning the locker room into a dictatorship with snacks.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
Practice begins in five minutes.
Bring your hunger.
We will sublimate it.

He steps away, then pauses.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. (CONT’D)
And Hank?

BIG HANK
Yes, Coach?

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
If you ever smuggle turkey again—

A beat.

COACH S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S.
—make it a convincing decoy.

He exits.

Big Hank sits there, holding the cube, staring at the banner.

SPOONER sits across from him.

SPOONER
You know you just got logic-mugged, right?

BIG HANK
Yeah.

SPOONER
How do you feel?

Big Hank looks at the cube like it’s a punishment from Zeus.

BIG HANK
Like my stomach just got recruited.

FADE OUT.

ASSISTANT (TO THE) GUARDIAN
SILVER CLASS

THE REPBUILIC — BENEFITS & SOUL COMPLIANCE OFFICE

JIM (TALKING HEAD)
So, we’ve reached the point in the apocalypse where… we’re doing benefits.
For a zombie.
And I just— I want to be clear—
this is not what I meant when I said I wanted better work-life balance.

CUT BACK TO SCENE.

DWIGHT
(to camera)
The Bronze Class health plan is not a handout.

DWIGHT (CONT’D)

JED
Good morning, team!
I brought muffins.

COMMUNAL MUFFIN CUBES (FLAVOR: CONSENSUS)

No one reacts.

JED (CONT’D)
Alright! Today is Open Enrollment.
And as Regional Manager and Philosopher King,
I want to say one thing:
in this Republic, nobody is left behind.
Unless Dwight says so.
Which is most people.
But not today.

DWIGHT
Correction. Today is *Socratic Audit Day.*

JED
Which is like Open Enrollment… but with questions.
Fun questions.
Truth questions.
Fun Truth.

Jim stares into the camera again.

JIM (TALKING HEAD)
He thinks “The Noble Lie” is a brand.
Like… Nike.
But for… ethics.

Dwight flips the clipboard to a clean page.

CLOSE ON: A form titled “BRONZE CLASS HEALTH PLAN ELIGIBILITY”
Checkboxes include:
☐ Has a pulse (flexible)

☐ Acknowledges the Noble Contract
☐ Can refrain from biting for 90 seconds
☐ Does not legally count as “equipment”

DWIGHT
(to Darkseeker)

DWIGHT
Writing that down as… “Cletus?”

JED
(excited)

(to camera, barely moving lips)
It is not named Cletus.

The Darkseeker HOWLS, trying to stand. The chair rolls a few inches.

DWIGHT
(interpreting)

JED slides into a chair with a notebook titled: PLATO FOR DUMMIES (WATERPROOF EDITION)

JED
Dwight, remember: the Socratic method is about guiding someone to the truth.

They are the same thing.
Different fonts.

DWIGHT (CONT’D)

Dwight checks a box:
☑ Demonstrates appetite

DWIGHT

Candidate must refrain from biting for ninety seconds.

On the paperwork.

LIQUID LOGIC (PEPPER SPRAY)

Dwight! No! That’s for town halls.

This is a town hall with worse breath.

Time.

So… it qualified?

DWIGHT
You cannot override the Audit.

JED
I can. I’m the Philosopher King.

Dwight’s eye twitches.

You are now Bronze Class.
You get:
one communal bandage per quarter,
access to the gym treadmill bulb on Tuesdays,
and vision coverage—

Dwight’s head snaps.

DWIGHT
WE DO NOT HAVE VISION COVERAGE!

JED
—of the Good.

Dwight turns to the camera, intense.

DWIGHT (TALKING HEAD)
This is why civilizations fall.
Not zombies.
Not nuclear winter.
Benefits creep.

Jim leans toward Pam, whispering.

JIM
So what’s the plan when it uses the health plan to… bite people?

PAM
I think the plan is we all pretend the shadows are better.

The Darkseeker calms slightly, then makes a strange, almost conversational SOUND. It stares at the muffin cubes.

JED
(hopeful)
See? It’s… adapting.

DWIGHT
It is calculating.

The Darkseeker suddenly jerks forward, not toward anyone’s neck—
but toward the tray of COMMUNAL MUFFIN CUBES.

It grabs one in its teeth and swallows.

Everyone watches.

A beat.

Then the Darkseeker emits a low, disappointed moan—as if realizing the end of the world has no flavor.

JED
(smiling, triumphant)
It worked.
Consensus.

Dwight narrows his eyes.

DWIGHT
No.
That was not consensus.

He points at the tray.

DWIGHT (CONT’D)
That was hunger settling for policy.

Jim stares into the camera.

JIM (TALKING HEAD)
This is the first time I’ve seen a zombie… regret.

BACK TO CONFERENCE ROOM.

Jed claps his hands.

JED
Great meeting!
Next item:
Potluck sign-up sheet.

Dwight lifts the clipboard.

DWIGHT
No.

JED
Dwight—

DWIGHT
The undead do not bring sides.

Jed turns to the Darkseeker.

JED
Can you bring a side?

The Darkseeker SCREECHES.

JED
That’s a “maybe.”
Love that energy.

Dwight sighs, defeated by bureaucracy itself.

DWIGHT
(to camera, deadpan)
The meeting started.
The world ended.
Justice is… apparently… a potluck.

The lights flicker. Somewhere outside the bunker doors, a distant chorus of Darkseekers bangs like an angry HR department.

FADE OUT.
